ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Coordination, basic introduction to engineering concepts.
insight on the mechanical design process, basic CAD and machine shop techniques, basically a litmus test on if you want to do mechanical engineering or not
I learned a lot about CAD, methods of fabrication (like laser cutting and 3D printing), and the iterative design process.
I learned how to use CAD, and developed skills in woodwork and craftsmanship. I collaborated with others and enhanced my leadership skills.

A basic introduction into brainstorming, designing, fabricating, assembling, and presenting a prototype geared toward a specific problem in a team setting. It also exposed me to techniques and machinery/equipment commonly seen in the engineering industry.

The lectures provide a comprehensive instruction on the mechanical design process. You use the lessons learned in weekly deliverables. 
Also, whatever your team project is will drive other learning aspects. Personally, I learned how to do some basic CAD and adobe illustrator. You also have to make a candle holder in the lab in the machine shop. That was pretty cool working the lathe.
I learned all about the process of creating a product. From generating an idea to testing parts of the prototype, this class helped me learn what making a machine includes all the way through.
Introduction to mechanical design methods and techniques. Class is mostly project based with lecture weeks scattered in between especially towards the beginning of the semester.

In this course I developed the skill to work without tools to do things that definitely required tools. I also learned how to learn things myself. This course gave me insight into how poorly a course can be managed, while still being a requirement for a major. This course was great for facilitating teamwork until the final project where everyone in your group was supposed to disregard that and fight over the best prototype.

Knowledge: general knowledge about the design process, including brainstorming, conducting FMEA, fabrication plans, etc.

Skills: machine shop training, CAD (OnShape), presentation and prototyping skills
I learned about the mechanical design process. I learned how to use some machines and how to use a drill.
Learned CAD, 3D printing, machining, idea design & iteration, teamwork, electronics
I learned how to build things. I'd never known how to use different powered and non-powered equipment before, and I feel a lot more comfortable with it now.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: really fun and engaging, lovely to learn about the design process, you get to go through the entire process of building your project, brainstorming all the concepts, learning how to use certain tools, etc
weaknesses: a large portion of your grade is based on how well your mechanical device (semester-long project) works at the end of the course, you brainstorm and decide on an idea fairly quickly, and some people don't scope the projects well so they have too much to develop and get stressed

This course is very hands-on and tasks its students (who have often not yet taken an engineering class) with large amounts of responsibility and creative freedom. It's a great course for a first-year engineering student because it will quickly allow them to decide whether or not they will want to continue with the major. I found the greatest weakness of this course to be that we were not given enough time to generate ideas for our project. We were presented a very lofty and broad problem statement about creating a device that helps with climate change, and then had under a week to determine what we would want our device to be. Considering that we had to stick with our original concept for the rest of the semester, it would have been helpful to have a bit more time to think of what we wanted to create.

This class made me realize that mechanical engineering is for me! The workload, however, was extremely intense and left many of the groups pulling all-nighters. Although I understand the thought process behind it, one prototype per group member was way too much, making it feel rushed and leaving us unable to produce our best work. It expects a thorough understanding of CAD, craftsmanship, and electronics, so teaching ourselves and completing these deadlines was extremely unreasonable. We should have done more CAD than one lab, as I feel all of the CAD ended up getting put on the one person that had any previous experience.

Strengths: very realistic and solid introduction to the world of engineering prototypes in a team setting. 
Weaknesses: feedback was sometimes not on time, would have been really nice to have our second design review feedback prior to the final presentation. It would have been helpful to learn a bit of hardware like a simple introduction to mechatronics

One strength of the course is its focus on one semester long project, which allows you to become invested in the mechanical design process.

It would be smoother if there was more time and focus on certain parts such as testing and creating prototypes

Like all project based engineering classes, the workload of this course ramps up extremely towards the end of the semester, but this is pretty typical. The lectures were effective in teaching the methods to come up with and evaluate ideas for engineering projects. The professor and TAs were all very helpful and approachable. 

The one change I would make to the class is the requirement for each person to make their own prototype. I felt it limited our teams ability to make design changes between the second design review and the final prototype because we knew we needed to set aside enough time to make one prototype each instead of focusing on just making one that was the highest quality

Strengths: 
-Allowed for creative use of "safe" tools
-Provided a wide range of things to learn
Weaknesses:
-We were not able to work on our physical project alone until halfway through the semester
-We were not allowed to use power/"unsafe" tools unless a TF was present
-TFs are also people so there were many times where our schedules would not allow us use of power tools
-Majority of lecture material had nothing to do with actual design, more to do with developing a product to sell
-Trouble learning things necessary as only one TF would really know how to do each thing and would have to wait for them to teach us
-Workload is massively backloaded as the beginning of the semester basically has nothing to do with the actual project, or is changed drastically once you begin designing
Improvements:
-Find some way of letting students use tools without there being a TF. We are college students and they did not trust us with drills or screw drivers or circular saws or anything that would be useful in a design class. I would suggest switching one of the early labs to be tool safety and then allow the students to use at least some of the tools
-Don't require one prototype per person, and grade individually. This is completely ridiculous. As every design group did, we specialized and had one person do electronics, one do cad, one do general assembly... There is no reason why we would need to build more than 2 prototypes if the goal is to display reproducibility. 
-Increase the budget per prototype. Similar to previous point, but just use the additional budget for the whole project, not per person.
-Spread out workload. Find a quicker way to get to actual design phase to allow for more time working on the main project of the class.

The strengths of this course are definitely the hands-on teaching by the professor and TAs; their feedback was invaluable, and not the bit condescending even for a student going in blind to this engineering course.

I do think the course workload could be rated a bit higher. Prototyping was particularly time consuming even outside of class and lab time. Sometimes the material in lecture didn't always bear on the design or prototyping process, though I'm should it would in a higher-level class.

I loved that this course is hands-on. I liked the machine shop training. More access to the lab would've been appreciated. I didn't like the new policy of one prototype per person. There were some design changes that my team considered making but we felt like we didn't have enough time, since we had to build multiple prototypes.

Strength: Learned a lot by doing the project, the prompt was relevant, the feedback was clear
Weakness: the class was very demanding b/c of how fast the timeline was. Training in CAD was more surface-level than hoped

Strengths: No tests, learn how to build things

Weaknesses: An incredible amount of time spent on things which did not add value. Such as, creating 4 different replicas of the same thing. Since CEID closes early, we had to hand screw tens of screws in awkward positions throughout the night, multiple nights. I'd also recommend starting CAD earlier. The first material is interesting, but starting with the fundamentals imo would be beneficial and allow for more efficient team efforts on product design

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would definitely recommend this course especially if you are looking into doing mechanical engineering! it's a good test to see if you want to be a mechanical engineer and learn about the design process. i came in knowing virtually nothing and having very little experience, so this class was really cool to validate my desires of becoming a mechanical engineer.
I would recommend this course to anyone considering majoring in mechanical engineering.

I would as I do feel I learned a lot and that I benefitted from this class. If this class goes back down to one prototype per group instead of one per person, I really feel this class would have been extremely enjoyable and I would have been able to learn a lot more and perfect my prototype.

Yes! It's a necessary course for the ABET MENG major but otherwise, it's still a really fun class (as long as you get a good TA and good team members) that gives you a glimpse into the world of engineering in industry with team members.
I would recommend this course to anyone curious about mechanical design. You'll still find ways to contribute in your group even if you feel your experience is lacking in certain technical areas.
Definitely. This course is a Mechanical Engineering requirement, but it also is great for anyone who wants an introduction to creating a mechanical product.

Yes, it was a fantastic course. The lectures were engaging and the project is overall a lot of fun. However, be prepared for the workload to ramp up rapidly during reading week. This is an inevitable feature of all project based classes as you WILL be rushing to put everything together at the end. The deliverables (weekly homework about progress) can also be pretty intense, but overall the class and project are very fun if you like building and ideation.
If you have to take it you have to take it. Could be fun if you get a group with a lot of prior knowledge.
I would definitely recommend this course to any curious student! Just be prepared to spend a lot of time learning with you hands.
Yes, it's a good course. Be aware that it might take a lot of your time in the last few weeks of the semester. It's a great introduction to mechanical design.
Yes! I really loved building the project, and I learned so many tangible skills
If workload was pulled back a bit, absolutely
